castList.head: [DRAMATIS PERSONAE

castItem.roleDesc: his brother, afterwards KNIG HENRY THE THIRD

castItem.role: SON TO THE DUKE OF GUISE

castList.castItem: Captain of the Guard, Protestants, Schoolmasters, Soldiers, Murderers, Attendants, &c.
MARGARET,her daughter, wife to the KING OF NAVARRE

castItem.role: Maid to the Duchess of Guise

body.head: The Massacre at Paris. With the Death of the Duke of Guise.

div1.head: [Scene i]
div1.stage: Enter Charles the French King, [Catherine] the Queene Mother, the King of Navarre, the Prince of Condye, the Lord high Admirall, and [Margaret] the Queene of Navarre, with others.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: Prince of Navarre my honourable brother,
Prince Condy, and my good Lord Admirall,
I wishe this union and religious league,
Knit in these hands, thus joyn'd in nuptiall rites,
May not desolve, till death desolve our lives,
And that the native sparkes of princely love,
That kindled first this motion in our hearts , :
May still be feweld in our progenye.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: The many favours which your grace hath has showne,
From time to time, but specially in this , :
Shall binde me ever to your highnes will,
In what Queen Mother or your grace commands.
Thanks sonne Navarre, you see we love you well,
That linke you in mariage with our daughter heer:

And as you know ,
our difference in Religion ,
Might be a meanes to crosse you in your love.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: Well Madam, let that rest:
And now my Lords the mariage rites perfourm'd,
We think it good to goe and consumate
The rest, with hearing of a an holy Masse:
Sister, I think your selfe will beare us company.

sp.speaker: Queene Margaret
sp.l: I will my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: The rest that will not goe (my Lords) may stay:
Come Mother ,
Let us goe to honor this solemnitie.
Which Ile desolve with bloud and crueltie.

div1.stage: Exit [Charles] the King, Queene Mother, and [Margaret] the Queene of Navar [with others], and manet Navar, the Prince of Condy, and the Lord high Admirall.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Prince Condy and my good Lord Admiral,
Now Guise may storme but doe does us little hurt:
Having the King, Queene Mother on our sides side ,
To stop the mallice of his envious heart,
That seekes to murder all the Protestants:
Have you not heard of late how he decreed,
If that the King had given consent thereto,
That all the protestants that are in Paris,
Should have been murdered the other night?

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: My Lord I mervaile that th'aspiring Guise ,
Dares once adventure without the Kings consent assent ,
To meddle or attempt such dangerous things.

sp.speaker: Condy
sp.l: My Lord you need not mervaile at the Guise,
For what he doth the Pope will ratifie:
In murder, mischeefe, or in tiranny.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: But he that sits and rules above the clowdes,
Doth heare and see the praiers of the just:
And will revenge the bloud of innocents,
That Guise hath slaine by treason of his heart,
And brought by murder to their timeles ends.

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: My Lord, but did you mark the Cardinall
The Guises brother, and the Duke Dumain:
How they did storme at these your nuptiall rites,
Because the house of Burbon now comes in,

And joynes your lineage to the crowne of
France
?

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: And thats the cause that Guise so frowns at us,
And beates his braines to catch us in his trap , :
Which he hath pitcht within his deadly toyle.
Come my Lords lets go to the Church and pray,
That God may still defend the right of France:
And make his Gospel flourish in this land.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: If ever Hymen lowr'd at marriage rites,
And had his alters decks with duskie lightes:
If ever sunne stainde heaven with bloudy clowdes,
And made it look with terrour on the worlde:
If ever day were turnde to ugly night,
And night made semblance of the hue of hell,
This day, this houre , hour and hour and this fatall night,
Shall fully shew the fury of them all . ,
Apothecarie. —

sp.speaker: Pothecarie
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Now shall I prove and guerdon to the ful,
The love thou bear'st unto the house of Guise:
Where are those perfumed gloves which which late I sent
To be poysoned, hast thou done them? speake,
Will every very savour breed a pangue of death?

sp.speaker: Pothecarie
sp.p:
See where they be my good
Lord, and he that smelles
but to them, dyes.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.p: Then thou remainest resolute.

sp.speaker: Pothecarie
sp.p:
I am my Lord, in what your grace commaundes till
death.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Thankes my good freend, I wil requite thy love . ,
Goe then, present them to the Queene Navarre:
For she is that huge blemish in our eye,
That makes these upstart heresies in Fraunce:
Be gone my freend, present them to her straite.
Souldyer. —

sp.speaker: Souldier
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Now come thou forth and play thy tragick part,
Stand in some window opening neere the street,
And when thou seest the Admirall ride by,
Discharge thy musket and perfourme his death:
And then Ile guerdon thee with store of crownes.

sp.speaker: Souldier
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l:
Now Guise ,
begins begin those deepe ingendred thoughts ,

To burst abroad ,
those never dying flames,
Which cannot be extinguisht but by bloud.
Oft have I leveld, and at last have learnd,
That perill Danger's is the cheefest way to happines joy ,
And resolution honors fairest aime.
What glory is there in a common good,
That hanges for every peasant to atchive?
That like I best that flyes beyond my reach . ,
Set me to scale the high Peramides,
And thereon set the Diadem of Fraunce,
Ile either rend it with my nayles to naught,
Or mount the top with my aspiring winges,
Although my downfall be the deepest hell.
For this, I wake, when others think I sleepe,
For this, I waite, that scornes scorn attendance else:
For this, my quenchles thirst whereon I builde,
Hath often pleaded kindred to the King.
For this, this head, this heart, this hand and sworde,

Contrives Contrive , imagines imagine
and
fully executes execute
,
Matters of importe, aimed aimde at by many,
Yet understoode by none.
For this, hath heaven engendred me of earth,
For this, this earth the earth sustaines my bodies weight,
And with this wait Ile counterpoise a Crowne,
Or with seditions weary all the worlde:

For this, from Spaine the stately Catholickes Catholic
,
Sends Send Indian golde to coyne me French ecues:
For this have I a largesse from the Pope,
A pension and a dispensation too:
And by that priviledge to worke upon,
My policye hath framde religion . ,
Religion: O Diabole.

Fye, I am ashamde ,
how ever that I seeme,
To think a word of such a simple sound,
Of so great matter should be made the ground.
The gentle King whose pleasure uncontrolde,
Weakneth his body, and will waste his Realme,
If I repaire not what he ruinates:
Him as a childe I dayly winne with words,
So that for proofe, he barely beares the name:
I execute, and he sustaines the blame.
The Mother Queene workes wonders for my sake,
And in my love entombes the hope of Fraunce:
Rifling the bowels of her treasurie,
To supply my wants and necessitie.
Paris hath full five hundred Colledges,
As Monestaries, Priories, Abbyes and halles,
Wherein are thirtie thousand able men,
Besides a thousand sturdy student Catholicks,

And more :
of my knowledge in one cloyster keeps keep ,
Five hundred fatte Franciscan Fryers and priestes.
All this and more, if more may be comprisde,
To Do bring the will whole of our desires to end.
Then Guise ,
Since thou hast all the Cardes , within thy hands
To shuffle or cut to cut , take this as surest thing:
That right or wrong, thou deale deal'st thy selfe a King.

I but, Navarre, Navarre Navarre
. Tis , tis but a nook of France.
Sufficient yet for such a pettie King:
That with a rablement of his hereticks,
Blindes Europs eyes and troubleth our estate:
Him will we —
But first lets follow those in France.
That hinder our possession procession to the crowne:
As Caesar to his souldiers, so say I:
Those that hate me, will I learn to loath.
Give me a look, that when I bend the browes,
Pale death may walke in furrowes of my face:
A hand, that with a graspe may gripe the world,
An eare, to heare what my detractors say,
A royall seate, a scepter and a crowne:
That those which doe beholde, they behold them may become
As men that stand and gase against the Sunne.
The plot is laide, and things shall come to passe , :
Where resolution strives for victory.

div1.head: [Scene iii]
div1.stage: Enter the King of Navar and Queen [Margaret], and his [olde] Mother Queen [of Navarre], the Prince of Condy, the Admirall, and the Pothecary with the gloves, and gives them to the olde Queene.

sp.speaker: Pothecarie
sp.p:
Maddame, I beseech your grace to except this simple
gift.

sp.speaker: Old Queene
sp.l:
Thanks my good freend, holde ,
take thou this reward.

sp.speaker: Pothecarie
sp.l: I humbly thank your Majestie.

sp.speaker: Old Queene
sp.l: Me thinkes the gloves have a very strong perfume,
The sent whereof doth make my head to ake.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Doth not your grace know the man that gave them you?

sp.speaker: Old Queene
sp.l: Not wel, but do remember such a man.

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: Your grace was ill advisde to take them then,
Considering of these dangerous times.

sp.speaker: Old Queene
sp.l:
Help sonne Navarre ,
I am poysoned.

sp.speaker: Queene Margaret
sp.l: The heavens forbid your highnes such mishap.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: The late suspition of the Duke of Guise,
Might well have moved your highnes to beware :
How you did meddle with such dangerous giftes.

sp.speaker: Queene Margaret
sp.l: Too late it is my Lord if that be true
To blame her highnes, but I hope it be
Only some naturall passion makes her sicke.

sp.speaker: Old Queene
sp.l: O no, sweet Margaret Margret , the fatall poyson
Workes Doth work Worketh Worketh within my head heart , my brain pan breakes,
My heart doth faint, I dye.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: My Mother poysoned heere before my face:
O gracious God, what times are these?
O graunt sweet God my daies may end with hers,
That I with her may dye and live againe.

sp.speaker: Queene Margaret
sp.l: Let not this heavy chaunce my dearest Lord,
(For whose effects my soule is massacred)
Infect thy gracious brest with fresh supply,
To agravate our sodaine miserie.

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: Come my Lords let us beare her body hence,
And see it honoured with just solemnitie.

div1.stage: As they are going, [enter] the Souldier [above, who] dischargeth his Musket at the Lord Admirall [and exit].

sp.speaker: Condy
sp.l: What are you hurt my Lord high Admiral?

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l:
I my good Lord ,
shot through the arme.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.p:
We are betraide, come my Lords, and let us goe tell
the King of this.

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: These are the cursed Guisians that doe seeke our death.
Oh fatall was this mariage to us all.

div1.stage: They beare away the [olde] Queene [of Navarre] and goe out.

div1.head: [Scene iv]
div1.stage: Enter [Charles] the King, [Catherinethe] Queene Mother, Duke of Guise, Duke Anjoy, Duke Demayne [and Cossin, Captain of the Kings Guard].

sp.speaker: Queene Mother
sp.l: My noble sonne, and princely Duke of Guise,
Now have we got the fatall stragling deere , :
Within the compasse of a deadly toyle,
And as we late decreed we may perfourme.
Madam, it wilbe noted through the world,
An action bloudy and tirannicall:
Cheefely since under safetie of our word,
They justly challenge their protection:
Besides my heart relentes that noble men,
Onely corrupted in religion,
Ladies of honor, Knightes and Gentlemen,
Should for their conscience taste such rutheles ends.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Though gentle minces should pittie others paines pain ,
Yet will the wisest note their proper greefes:
And rather seeke to scourge their enemies,
Then be themselves base subjects to the whip.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Me thinkes my Lord, Anjoy hath well advisde ,
Your highnes to consider of the thing,
And rather chuse to seek your countries good,
Then pittie or releeve these upstart hereticks.

sp.speaker: Queene Mother
sp.l: I hope these reasons mayserve my princely, Sonne,
To have some care for feare of enemies.
Well Madam, I referre it to your Majestie,
And to my Nephew heere the Duke of Guise:
What you determine, I will ratifie.

sp.speaker: Queene Mother
sp.l: Thankes to my princely sonne, then tell me Guise,
What order wil you set downe for the Massacre?

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Thus Madame.
They that shalbe actors in this Massacre,
Shall weare white crosses on their Burgonets , :
And tye white linnen scarfes about their armes.
He that wantes these, and is suspected suspect of heresie,
Shall dye, be or be he King or Emperour.
Then Ile have a peale of ordinance shot from the tower,
At which they all shall issue out and set the streetes.
And then the watchword being given, a bell shall ring,
Which when they heare, they shall begin to kill:
And never cease untill that bell shall cease,
Then breath a while.
How now fellow, what newes?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.l: And it please your grace the Lord high Admirall,
Riding the streetes was traiterously shot,
And most humbly humble intreates your Majestie
To visite him sick in his bed.
Messenger, tell him I will see him straite.
What shall we doe now with the Admirall?

sp.speaker: Queene Mother
sp.l: Your Majesty were had best goe visite him,
And make a shew as if all were well.

sp.speaker: Charles
sp.l: Content, I will goe visite the Admirall.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: And I will goe take order for his death.

div1.stage: Enter the Admirall in his bed.

sp.l: How fares it with my Lord high Admiral,
Hath he been hurt with villaines in the street?
I vow and sweare as I am King of France,
To finde and to repay the man with death:
With death delay'd and torments never usde,
That durst presume for hope of any gaine,
To hurt the noble man their his sovereign loves.

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: Ah my good Lord, these are the Guisians,
That seeke to massacre our guiltles lives.
Assure your selfe my good Lord Admirall,
I deepely sorrow for your trecherous wrong:
And that I am not more secure my selfe,
Then I am carefull you should be preserved.
Cossin, take twenty of our strongest guarde,
And under your direction see they keep ,
All trecherous violence from our noble freend,
Repaying all attempts with present death,
Upon the cursed breakers of our peace.
And so be pacient good Lord Admirall,
And every hower I will visite you.

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: I humbly thank your royall Majestie.

div1.head: [Scene v]
div1.stage: Enter Guise, Anjoy, Dumaine, Gonzago, Retes, Montsorrell, and Souldiers to the massacre.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Anjoy, Dumaine, Gonzago, Retes, sweare by
The argent crosses in on your burgonets,
To kill all that you suspect of heresie.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: I sweare by this to be unmercifull.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: I am disguisde and none nows who I am , .
And therfore meane to murder all I meet.

sp.speaker: Gonzago
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: Retes
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Away then, break into the Admirals house.

sp.speaker: Getes
sp.l: I let the Admirall be first dispatcht.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: The Admirall ,
Cheefe standard bearer to the Lutheranes,
Shall in the entrance of this Massacre,
Be murdered in his bed.
Gonzago conduct them thither hither , and then
Beset his house that not a man may live.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: That charge is mine . , Swizers keepe you the streetes,
And at ech corner shall the Kings garde stand.

sp.speaker: Gonzago
sp.l: Come sirs follow me.

div1.stage: Exit Gonzago and others with him.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Cossin, the Captaine of the Admirals guarde,
Plac'd by my brother, will betray his Lord:
Now Guise shall catholiques flourish once againe,
The head being of, the members cannot stand.

sp.speaker: Retes
sp.l: But look my Lord, ther's some in the Admirals house.

div1.stage: Enter [above Gonzago and others] into the Admirals house, and he in his bed.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: In lucky time, come let us keep this lane,
And slay his servants that shall issue out.

sp.speaker: Gonzago
sp.l: Where is the Admirall?

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: O let me pray before I dye.

sp.speaker: Gonzago
sp.l: Then pray unto our Ladye, kisse this crosse.

sp.speaker: Admirall
sp.l: O God forgive my sins.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l:
Gonzago,
what What , is he dead Gonzago ?

sp.speaker: Gonzago
sp.l: I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Then throw him down.

div1.stage: [The body is thrown down. Exeunt Gonzago and rest above.]

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Now cosin view him well,
It may be it is some other, and he escapte.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Cosin tis he, I know him by his look.
See where my Souldier shot him through the arm.
He mist him neer, but we have strook him now.

Ah base
Shatillian
and degenerate,
Cheef standard bearer to the Lutheranes,
Thus in despite of thy Religion,
The Duke of Guise stampes on thy liveles bulke.
Away with him, cut of his head and handes , .
And send them for a present to the Pope:
And when this just revenge is finished,
Unto mount Faucon will we dragge his coarse:
And he that living hated so the crosse,
Shall being dead, be hangd thereon in chaines.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Anjoy, Gonzago, Retes, if that you three,
Will be as resolute as I and Dumaine:
There shall not not be a Hugonet breath in France.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: I sweare by this crosse, wee'l not be partiall,
But slay as many as we can come neer.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Mountsorrett, goe go and shoote the ordinance of,
That they which have already set the street
May know their watchword, then and then then go tole the bell,
And so lets forward to the Massacre.

sp.speaker: Mountsorrell
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: And now my Lords lord let us closely to our busines.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Anjoy will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: And so will Dumaine.

div1.stage: The ordinance being shot of, the bell tolles.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Come then, lets away.

div1.stage: The Guise enters againe, with all the rest, with their Swords drawne, chasing the Protestants.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Let none escape, murder the Hugonets.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Kill them, kill them.

div1.stage: Enter Loreine running, the Guise and the rest pursuing him.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Loreine, Loreine, follow Loreine . , . Sirra,
Are you a preacher of these heresies?

sp.speaker: Loreine
sp.l: I am a preacher of the word of God,
And thou a traitor to thy soule and him.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Dearely beloved brother, thus tis written.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Stay my Lord, let me begin the psalme.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Come dragge him away and throw him in a ditch.

div1.head: [Scene vi]
div1.stage: Enter Mountsorrell and knocks at Serouns doore.

sp.speaker: Serouns wife
sp.l: Who is that which is't that knocks there?

sp.speaker: Mountsorrell
sp.l: Mountsorrett from the Duke of Guise.

sp.speaker: Serouns wife
sp.p:
Husband come down, heer's one would speak with
you from the Duke of Guise.

sp.speaker: Seroune
sp.l: To speek with me from such a man as he?

sp.speaker: Mountsorrell
sp.l: I, I, for this Seroune, and thou shalt ha't hate .

sp.speaker: Seroune
sp.l: O let me pray before I take my death.

sp.speaker: Mountsorrell
sp.l: Despatch then quickly.

sp.speaker: Seroune
sp.l: O Christ my Saviour-- .

sp.speaker: Mountsorrell
sp.l: Christ, villaine?

Why ,
darst thou presume to call on Christ,
Without the intercession of some Saint?
Sanctus Sancta Jacobus hee was he is he's my Saint, pray to him.
O let me pray unto my God.

sp.speaker: Mountsorrell
sp.l: Then take this with you.

div1.stage: Stab him [and he falls within and dies].

div1.head: [Scene vii]

sp.speaker: Ramus
sp.l: What fearfull cries comes come from the river Sene,
That frightes fright poore Ramus sitting at his book?
I feare the Guisians have past the bridge,
And meane once more to menace me.

sp.speaker: Taleus
sp.l: Flye Ramus flye, if thou wilt save thy life.

sp.speaker: Ramus
sp.l: Tell me Taleus, wherfore should I flye?

sp.speaker: Taleus
sp.l: The Guisians are hard at thy doore,
And meane to murder us:
Harke, harke they come, Ile leap out at the window.

sp.speaker: Ramus
sp.l: Sweet Taleus stay.

sp.speaker: Gonzago
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Retes
sp.l: Tis Taleus, Ramus bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Gonzago
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Taleus
sp.l: I am as Ramus is, a Christian.

sp.speaker: Retes
sp.l: O let him goe, he is a catholick.

sp.speaker: Gonzago
sp.l: Come Ramus, more golde, or thou shalt have the stabbe.

sp.speaker: Ramus
sp.l: Alas I am a scholler, how should I have golde?
All that I have is but my stipend from the King,
Which is no sooner receiv'd but it is spent.

div1.stage: Enter the Guise and Anjoy [, Dumaine, Mountsorrell, with soldiers].

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Who Whom have you there?

sp.speaker: Retes
sp.l: Tis Ramus, the Kings professor of Logick.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Stab him.

sp.speaker: Ramus
sp.l: O good my Lord,
Wherein hath Ramus been so offencious ? .

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Marry sir, in having a smack in all,
And yet didst never sound any thing to the depth.
Was it not thou that scoftes scoff'dst the Organon,
And said it was a heape of vanities?
He that will be a flat decotamest,
And seen in nothing but Epitomies Epetomies :
Is in your judgment thought a learned man.

And he forsooth must goe and preach in
Germany
:
Excepting against Doctors axioms actions ,
And ipse ipsi dixi with this quidditie,

l.foreign: Argumentum testimonii testimonis est inartificiale in arte fetiales in arte partialis .

sp.l: To contradict which, I say Ramus shall dye:
How answere you that? your nego argumentum

Cannot serve, sirra Sirrah
: , kill him.

sp.speaker: Ramus
sp.l: O good my Lord, let me but speak a word.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Well, say on.

sp.speaker: Ramus
sp.l: Not for my life doe I desire this pause,
But in my latter houre to purge my selfe,
In that I know the things that I have wrote,
Which as I heare one Shekius Shekins takes it ill , :
Because my places being but three, contains contain all his:
I knew the Organon to be confusde,
And I reduc'd it into better forme.
And this for Aristotle will I say,
That he that despiseth him, can nere
Be good in Logick or Philosophie.
And thats because the blockish Sorbonests thorbonest
Attribute as much unto their their own workes,
As to the service of the eternall God.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Why suffer you that peasant to declaime?
Stab him I say and send him to his freends in hell.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Nere was there Colliars sonne so full of pride.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l:
My Lord of
Anjoy, there are a hundred Protestants , .
Which we have chaste into the river Sene,
That swim about and so preserve their lives:
How may we doe? I feare me they will live.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: Goe place some men upon the bridge,
With bowes and cartes to shoot at them they see,
And sinke them in the river as they swim.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l:
Tis well advisde Dumain
, goe see it strait be
done.

And
in the mean time my Lord, could we devise,
To get those pedantes from the King Navarre,
That that are tutors to him and the prince of Condy — .

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l:
For that let me alone, Cousin stay you
heer,
And when you see me in, then follow hard.
sp.stage: He knocketh, and enter the King of Navarre and Prince of Condy, with their scholmaisters.
sp.l: How now my Lords, how fare you?

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: My Lord, they say
That all the protestants are massacred.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: I, so they are, but yet what remedy:
I have done what all I could to stay this broile.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: But yet my Lord the report doth run,
That you were one that made this Massacre.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Who I ? , you are deceived, I rose but now

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Murder the Hugonets, take those pedantes hence.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Thou traitor Guise, lay of thy bloudy hands.

sp.speaker: Condy
sp.l: Come let us goe tell the King.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Come sirs, Ile whip you to death with my punniards point.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Away A way with them both.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l:
And now sirs
for this night let our fury stay.

Yet will we not that
the Massacre shall end : ,
Gonzago posse you to Orleance, Retes to Deep,
Mountsorrell unto Roan, and spare not one
That you suspect of heresy. And now stay
That bel that to the devils mattins midnight matins rings .

Now
. every man put of his burgonet,
And so convey him closely to his bed.

div1.head: [Scene viii]
div1.stage: Enter Anjoy, with two Lords of Poland.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l:
My Lords of
Poland
I must needs confesse,
The offer of your Prince Electors Elector's Electors' , farre
Beyond the reach of my desertes:

For
Poland
is as I have been enformde,
A martiall people, worthy such a King,
As hath sufficient counsaile in himselfe,
To lighten doubts and frustrate subtile foes.
And such a King whom practice long hath taught,
To please himselfe with mannage of the warres , .
The greatest warres within our Christian bounds,
I meane our warres against the Muscovites Muscovite :
And on the other side against the Turke,
Rich Princes both, and mighty Emperours:
Yet by my brother Charles our King of France,
And by his graces councell it is thought,
That that if I undertake to weare the crowne

Of
Poland
, it may prejudice their hope
Of my inheritance to the crowne of France:
For if th'almighty take my brother hence,
By due discent the Regall seat is mine.

With
Poland
therfore must I covenant thus,
That if by death of Charles, the diadem
Of France be cast on me, then with your leaves
I may retire me to my native home.
If your commission serve to warrant this,
I thankfully shall undertake the charge
Of you and yours, and carefully maintaine
The the wealth and safety of your kingdomes right.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: All this and more your highnes shall commaund,

For
Poland
s crowne and kingly diadem.

sp.speaker: Anjoy
sp.l: Then come my Lords lord , lets goe.

div1.head: [Scene ix]
div1.stage: Enter two with the Admirals body.

sp.p: Now sirra, what shall we doe with the Admirall?
Why let us burne him for an a heretick.>

O no, his bodye will infect the fire, and the fire the aire, and
so we shall be poysoned with him.
What shall we doe then?
Lets throw him into the river.

Oh twill corrupt the water, and the water the fish, and by
the
fish our selves when we eate cate them.
Then throw him into the ditch.

No, no, to decide all doubts, be rulde by me, lets hang him
heere
upon this tree.
Agreede.

div1.stage: Enter the Duke of Guise, and Queene Mother, and the Cardinall [of Loraine].

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Now Madame, how like you do you like our lusty Admirall?

sp.speaker: Queene Mother
sp.l: Beleeve me Guise he becomes the place so well,
As That I could long ere this have wisht him there.

But come lets walke aside, th'airs thair's not very
sweet.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: No by my faith Madam.
Sirs, take him away and throw him in some ditch.
And now Madam as I understand,
There a an re a hundred Hugonets and more,
Which in the woods doe horde their synagogue:
And dayly meet about this time of day,

And
thither will I to put them to the sword.

sp.speaker: Queene Mother
sp.l: Doe so sweet Guise, let us delay no time,
For if these straglers gather head againe,
And disperse themselves throughout the Realme of France,
It will be hard for us to worke their deaths.
Be gone, delay no time sweet Guise.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Madam,
I goe as whirl-winces rage before a storme.

sp.speaker: Queene Mother
sp.l:
My Lord of
Loraine
have you marks of late,
How Charles our sonne begins for to lament :
For the late nights worke which my Lord of Guise
Did make in Paris amongst among the Hugonites?

sp.speaker: Cardinall
sp.l: Madam, I have heard him solemnly vow,
With the rebellious King of Navarre,

For
to revenge their deaths upon us all.

sp.speaker: Queene Mother
sp.l: I, but my Lord, let me alone for that,
For Katherine must have her will in France:
As I doe live, so surely shall he dye , .
And Henry then shall weare the diadem.
And if he grudge or crosse his Mothers will,
Ile disinherite him and all the rest:
For Ile rule France, but they shall weare the crowne:
And if they storme, I then may pull them downe.
Come my Lord let us lets us let's goe.

div1.head: [Scene x]
div1.stage: Enter five or sixe Protestants with bookes, and kneele together.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Downe with the Hugonites, murder them.

sp.speaker: Protestant
sp.l: O Mounser de Guise, heare me but speake.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: No villain, no that toung of thine,
That hath blasphemde the holy Church of Rome,
Shall drive no plaintes into the Guises eares,
To make the justice of my heart relent:
Tue, tue, tue, let none escape: Kill them.
So, dragge them away.

div1.head: [Scene xi]
div1.stage: Enter [Charles] the King of France, Navar and Epernoune staying him: enter Queene Mother, and the Cardinall [of Loraine, and Pleshe].

sp.l: O let me stay and rest me heer a while,
A griping paine hath ceasde upon my heart:
A sodaine pang, the messenger of death.
O say not so, thou kill'st thy mothers heart.
I must say so, paine forceth me complaine to complain .

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Comfort your selfe my Lord and I have no doubt,
But God will sure restore you to your health.
O no, my loving brother of Navarre.
I have deserv'd a scourge I must confesse,
Yet is their there pacience of another sort,
Then to misdoe the welfare of their King:
God graunt my neerest freends may prove no worse.
O horde me up, my sight begins to faire,
My sinnewes shrinke, my braines turne brain turns upside downe,
My heart doth break, I faint and dye.
What art thou dead, sweet sonne ? speak to thy Mother . ,
O no, his soule is fled from out his breast,
And he nor heares, nor sees us what we doe:

My Lords, what resteth there
now for
to be done?
But that we presently despatch Embassadours

To
Poland
, to call Henry back againe,
To weare his brothers crowne and dignity.
Epernoune, goe see it presently be done,
And bid him come without delay to us.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: Madam, I will.

And now my Lords after these funerals be
done,

We will with all the speed we can ,
provide ,
For Henries coronation from Polonie Polonia :
Come let us take his body hence.

div1.stage: All goe out, but Navarre and Pleshe.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l:
And now Navarre Pleshé Pleshé
whilste that these broiles doe last,
My opportunity may serve me it fit,
To steale from France, and hye me to my home.
For heers there's no saftie in the Realme for me,
And now that Henry is cal'd from Polland,
It is my due by just succession:
And therefore as speedily as I can perfourme,
Ile muster up an army secretdy,

For feare that Guise joyn'd with the King of
Spaine
,
Might seeme seek to crosse me in mine enterprise.
But God that alwaies doth defend the right,
Will shew his mercy and preserve us still.

sp.speaker: Pleshe
sp.l: The vertues of our true poor Religion,
Cannot but march with many graces more:
Whose army shall discomfort all your foes,
And at the length in Pampelonia crowne,

In spite of
Spaine
and all the popish power,
That hordes it from your highnesse wrongfully:
Your Majestie her rightfull Lord and Soveraigne.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Truth Pleshe, and God so prosper me in all,
As I entend to labour for the truth,
And true profession of his holy word:
Come Pleshe, lets away whilste while time doth serve.

div1.head: [Scene xii]
div1.stage: Sound Trumpets within, and then all crye vive le Roy two or three times.
Enter Henry crowned: Queene [Mother], Cardinall [of Loraine], Duke of Guise, Epernoone, [Mugeroun,] the kings Minions, with others, and the Cutpurse.

l.foreign: Vive le Roy, vive le Roy.

sp.l:
Welcome from
Poland
Henry once agayne,
Welcome to France thy fathers royall seate,
Heere hast thou a country voice of feares foes ,
A warlike people to maintaine thy right,
A watchfull Senate for ordaining lawes,
A loving mother to preserve thy state,
And all things that a King may wish besides:
All this and more hath Henry with his crowne.

sp.speaker: Cardinall
sp.l: And long may Henry enjoy all this and more.

l.foreign: Vive le Roy, vive le Roy.

sp.l: Thanks to you al. The guider of all crownes,
Graunt that our deeds may wel deserve your loves:
And so they shall, if fortune speed my will,
And yeeld your our thoughts to height of my desertes.
What saies say our Minions, think they Henries heart
Will not both harbour love and Majestie?
Put of that feare, they are already joynde,
No person, place, or time, or circumstance,
Shall slacke my loves affection affections from his bent . ,
As now you are, so shall you still persist ,
Remooveles from the favours of your King.

sp.speaker: Mugeroun
sp.l: We know that noble minces change not their thoughts
For wearing of a crowne: in that your grace,

Hath worne the
Poland
diadem, before
You you were in with vested in the crowne of France.
I tell thee Mugeroun we will be freends,
And fellowes to, what ever stormes arise.

sp.speaker: Mugeroun
sp.l: Then may it please your Majestie to give me leave,
To punish those that doe dare prophane this holy feast.

div1.stage: He cuts of the Cutpurse eare, for cutting of the golde buttons off his cloake.

sp.l: How meanst thou that?

sp.speaker: Cutpurse
sp.l: O Lord, mine eare.

sp.speaker: Mugeroun
sp.l: Come sir, give me my buttons and heers your eare.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Sirra, take him away.
Hands of good fellow, I will be his baile
For this offence: goe sirra, worke no more,
Till this our Coronation day be past:
And now ,

Our solemne
rites of Coronation done,
What now remaines, but for a while to feast,
And spend some daies in barriers, tourny, tylte,
And and like disportes, such as doe fit the Coutr?
Lets goe my Lords, our dinner staies for us.

div1.stage: Goe out all, but the Queene [Mother] and the Cardinall.

sp.l: My Lord Cardinall of Loraine, tell me,
How likes your grace my sonnes pleasantnes?
His mince you see runnes on his minions,
And all his heaven is to delight himselfe:
And whilste he sleepes securely thus in ease,
Thy brother Guise and we may now provide,
To plant our selves with such authoritie,
As That as not a man may live without our leaves.
Then shall the Catholick faith of Rome,
Flourish in France, and none deny the same.

sp.speaker: Cardinall
sp.l: Madam, as in secrecy I as I in secresy was tolde,
My brother Guise hath gathered a power of men,
Which are as he saith, to kill the Puritans,
But tis the house of Burbon that he meanest
Now Madam must you insinuate with the King,
And tell him that tis for his Countries good,
And common profit of Religion.
Tush man, let me alone with him,
To work the way to bring this thing to passe:
And if he doe deny what I doe say,
Ile dispatch him with his brother presently . ,
And then shall Mounser weare the diadem.
Tush, all shall dye unles I have my will:
For while she lives Katherine will be Queene.
Come my Lord Lords , let us goe seek to seek the Guise,
And then determine of this enterprise.

div1.head: [Scene xiii]
div1.stage: Enter the Duchesse of Guise, and her Maide.

sp.speaker: Duchesse
sp.l: Goe fetch me pen and inke.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I will Madam.

sp.speaker: Duchesse
sp.l: That I may write unto my dearest Lord.
Sweet Mugeroune, tis he that hath my heart,
And Guise usurpes it, cause I am his wife:
Faine would I finde some means to speak with him
But cannot, and therfore am enforst to write,
That he may come and meet me in some place,
Where we may one injoy the others sight.
sp.stage: Enter the Maid with Inke and Paper.
sp.l: So, set it down and leave me to my selfe.
O would to God this quill that heere doth write, She writes.
Had late been plucks from out faire Cupids wing:
That it might print these lines within his heart.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: What, all alone my love, and writing too:
I prethee say to whome thou writes?

sp.speaker: Duchesse
sp.l:
To such a one my Lord
, as when she reads my lines,
Will laugh I feare me at their good aray.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: I pray thee let me see.

sp.speaker: Duchesse
sp.l: O no my Lord, a woman only must
Partake the secrets of my heart.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: But Madam I must see. He takes it.
Are these your secrets that no man must know?

sp.speaker: Duchesse
sp.l: O pardon me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Thou trothles and unjust, what lines are these?
Am I growne olde, or is thy lust growne yong,
Or hath my love been so obscurde in thee,
That others needs need to comment on my text?
Is all my love forgot which helde thee deare?
I, dearer then the apple of mine eye?
Is Guises glory but a clowdy mist,
In sight and judgement of thy lustfull eye?
Mor du, wert were not the fruit within thy wombe,
Of On whose encrease I set some longing hope:
This wrathfull hand should strike thee to the hart
Hence strumpet, hide thy head for shame,
And fly my presence if thou looke look'st to live. Exit [Duchesse].
O wicked sexe, perjured and unjust,
Now doe I see that from the very first,
Her eyes and lookes sow'd seeds of perjury,
But villaine he to whom these lines should goe,
Shall buy her love even with his dearest bloud.

div1.head: [Scene xiv]
div1.stage: Enter the King of Navarre, Pleshe and Bartus, and their train, with drums and trumpets.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: My Now Lords, sith since in a quarrell just and right,
We undertake to mannage these our warres :
Against the proud disturbers of the faith,

I meane the Guise, the Pope, and King of
Spaine
,
Who set themselves to tread us under foot,
And rent rend our true religion from this land : .
But for you know our quarrell is no more,
But to defend their strange inventions,
Which they will put us to with sword and fire:
We must with resolute minces resolve to fight,
In honor of our God and countries good.

Spaine
is the counsell chamber of the pope,

Spaine
is the place where he makes peace and warre,

And Guise for
Spaine
hath now incenst the King,
To send his power to meet us in the field.

sp.speaker: Bartus
sp.l: Then in this bloudy brunt they may beholde,
The sole endevour of your princely care,
To plant the true succession of the faith,

In spite of
Spaine
and all his heresies.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: The power of vengeance now incampes implants it selfe,
Upon the hauty mountains of my brest:
Plaies plaies with her goary coulours of revenge,
Whom I respect as leaves of boasting greene,
That change their coulour when the winter comes,
When I shall vaunt as victor in revenge.
How now sirra, what newes?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: My Lord, as by our scoutes we understande,
A mighty army comes from France with speed:
Which are is already mustered in the land,
And meanes mean to meet your highnes in the field.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: In Gods name, let them come.
This is the Guise that hath incenst the King,
To leavy armes and make these civill broyles:
But canst thou tell tell me who is their generall?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Not yet my Lord, for thereon doe they stay:
But as report doth goe, the Duke of Joyeux
Hath made great sute unto the King therfore.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: It will not countervaile his paines I hope,
I would the Guise in his steed might have come,
But he doth lurke within his drousie couch,
And makes his footstoole on securitie:
So he be safe he cares not what becomes,
Of King or Country, no not for them both.
But come my Lords, let us away with speed,
And place our selves in order for the fight.

div1.head: [Scene xv]
div1.stage: Enter [Henry] the King of France, Duke of Guise, Epernoune, and Duke Joyeux.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My sweet Joyeux, I make thee Generall,
Of all my army now in readines,
To march against the rebellious King Navarre:
At thy request I am content thou goe go'st ,
Although my love to thee can hardly suffer't suffer suffer it ,
Regarding still the danger of thy life.

sp.speaker: Joyeux
sp.l: Thanks to your Majestie, and so I take my leave.

Farwell to
my Lord of Guise and Epernoune.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Health and harty farwell to my Lord Joyeux.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l:
So How kindely Cosin of
Guise you and your wife
Doe both salute our lovely Minions.
sp.stage: He makes hornes at the Guise.
sp.l: Remember you the letter gentle sir,
Which your wife writ to my deare Minion,
And her chosen freend?

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: How now my Lord, faith this is more then need,
Am I thus to be to be thus jested at and scornde?
Tis more then kingly or Emperious.
And sure if all the proudest Kings kings beside
In Christendome, should beare me such derision , :

They should know how
I scornde them and their mockes.
I love your Minions ? , dote on them your selfe,
I know none els but hordes them in disgrace disgust :
And heer by all the Saints in heaven I sweare,
That villain for whom I beare this deep disgrace , :
Even for your words that have incenst me so,
Shall buy that strumpets favour with his blood , .
Whether he have dishonoured me or no.

l.foreign: Par la mor du, Il mora.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Beleeve me , Epernoune this jest bites sore.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: My Lord, twere good to make them frends ,
For his othes are seldome spent in vaine.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How now Mugeroun, metst thou not the Guise at the doore?

sp.speaker: Mugeroun
sp.l: Not I my Lord, what if I had?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Marry if thou hadst, thou mightst have had the stab,
For he hath solemnely sworne thy death.

sp.speaker: Mugeroun
sp.l: I may be stabd, and live till he be dead,
But wherfore beares he me such deadly hate?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Because his wife beares thee such kindely love.

sp.speaker: Mugeroun
sp.l: If that be all, the next time that I meet her,
Ile make her shake off love with her heeles.
But which way is he gone ? , Ile goe take make a walk
On purpose from the Court to meet with him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I like not this, come Epernoune
Lets goe seek the Duke and make them freends.

div1.head: [Scene xvi]
div1.stage: Alarums within. The Duke Joyeux slaine.
Enter the King of Navarre [, Bartus,] and his traine.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: The Duke is slaine and all his power dispearst,
And we are grac'd with wreathes of victory:
Thus God we see doth ever guide the right,
To make his glory great upon the earth.

sp.speaker: Bartus
sp.l: The terrour of this happy victory,
I hope will make the King surcease his hate:
And either never mannage army more,
Or else employ them in some better cause.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: How many noble men have lost their lives,
In prosecution of these quell armes,
Is ruth and almost death to call to mince:
Put God we know will alwaies put them downe,
That lift themselves against the perfect truth,
Which Ile maintaine so as long as life doth last:
And with the Queene of England joyne my force,
To beat the papall Monarck from our lands,
And keep those relicks prelates from our countries coastes.

Come my Lords ,
now that
this the storme is overpass,
Let us away with triumph to our tents.

div1.head: [Scene xvii]

sp.speaker: Souldier
sp.p:
Sir, to you sir, that dares dare make the Duke a cuckolde,
and use a counterfeite key to his privie Chamber doore: And
although you take out nothing but your owne, yet you put in
that which displeaseth him, and so forestall his market, and set up
your standing where you should not: and whereas tree is your
Landlord, you will would take upon you to be his, and tyll the ground
that he himself should occupy, which is his own free land. If it be
not too free there's the question: and though I come not to take
possession (as I would I might) yet I meane to keepe you out,
which I will if this geare horde: what are ye come so soone?
have at ye sir.

div1.stage: He shootes at him and killes him.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Holde thee tall Souldier, take thee thou this and flye.
Lye there the Kings delight, and Guises scorne.
Revenge it Henry as thou list list'st or dare dar'st ,
I did it only in despite of thee.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My Lord of Guise, we understand that you
Have gathered a power of men . ,
What your intent is yet we cannot learn,
But we presume it is not for our good.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Why I am no traitor to the crowne of France.
What I have done tis for the Gospell Gospel's sake.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: Nay for the Popes sake, and shine owne benefite.
What Peere in France but thou (aspiring Guise)
Durst be in armes without the Kings consent?
I challenge thee for treason in the cause.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Ah Oh base Epernoune, were not his highnes heere,
Thou shouldst perceive the Duke of Guise is mov'd.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Be patient Guise and threat not Epernoune,
Least thou perceive the King Kiug of France be mov'd.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Why? I am a Prince of the Valoyses Valois line,
Therfore an enemy to the Burbonites.
I am a juror in the holy league,
And therfore hated of the Protestants.
What should I doe but stand upon my guarde?
And being able, Ile keep an hoast in pay.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: Thou able to maintaine an hoast in pay,
That livest by forraine exhibition ? .

The Pope and King of
Spaine
are thy good frends,
Else all France knowes how poor a Duke thou art.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I, those are they that feed him with their golde,
To countermaund our will and check our freends.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: My Lord, to speak more plainely, thus it is:
Being animated by Religious zeale,
I meane to muster all the power I can,
To overthrow those sectious sexious factious Puritans:

And know my Lord
, the Pope will sell his triple crowne ,

I, and the catholick Philip King of
Spaine
,
Ere I shall want, will cause his Indians,
To rip the golden bowels of America.
Navarre that cloakes clucks them underneath his wings,
Shall feele the house of Lorayne is his foe:
Your highnes needs need not feare mine armies force,
Tis for your safetie and your enemies wrack.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Guise, weare our crowne, and be thou King of France,
And as Dictator make or warre or peace,
Whilste I cry placet like a Senator . ,
I cannot brook thy hauty insolence,
Dismisse thy campe or else by our Edict,
Be thou proclaimde a traitor throughout France.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: The choyse is hard, I must dissemble. [Aside.]
My Lord, in token of my true humilitie,
And simple meaning to your Majestie , :
I kisse your graces hand, and take my leave,
Intending to dislodge my campe with speed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Then farwell Guise, the King and thou are art freends.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: But trust him not my Lord,

For had your highnesse ,
seene but seen with what a pompe
He entred Paris, and how the Citizens
With gifts and shewes did entertaine him
And promised to be at his commaund:
Nay, they fear'd not to speak in it in the streetes,
That the Guise Guise ch, durst stand in armes against the King,
For not effecting of his holines will.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Did they of Paris entertaine him so?
Then meanes he present treason to our state.
Well, let me alone, whose within there?
sp.stage: Enter one with e pen and inke.
sp.l: Make a discharge of all my counsell straite,
And Ile subscribe my name and seale it straight.
My head shall be my counsell, they are false:
And Epernoune I will be rulde by thee.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: My Lord,

I think for safety of your royall
person,
It would be good the Guise were made away,
And so to quite your grace of all suspect.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: First let us set our hand and seale to this,
And then Ile tell thee what I meane to doe. He writes.
So, convey this to the counsell presently. Exit one.
And Epernoune though I seeme milde and calme,
Thinke not but I am tragicall within:
Ile secretly convey me unto Bloyse,
For now that Paris takes the Guises parse,
Heere is no not staying for the King of France,
Unles he meane means to be betraide and dye:
But as I live, so sure the Guise shall dye.

div1.head: [Scene xviii]
div1.stage: Enter the King of Navarre reading of a letter, and Bartus.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: My Lord, I am advertised from France,

That the
Guise
hath taken armes against the King,
And that Paris is revolted from his grace.

sp.speaker: Bartus
sp.l: Then hath your grace fit oportunitie,
To shew your love unto the King of France:
Offering him aide against his enemies,
Which cannot but be thankfully receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Bartus, it shall be so, poast then to Fraunce,
And there salute his highnesse in our name,
Assure him all the aide we can provide,
Against the Guisians and their complices.
Bartus be gone, commend me to his grace,
And tell him ere it be long, Ile visite him.

sp.speaker: Bartus
sp.l: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l:
Pleshe
.

sp.speaker: Pleshe
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Pleshe, goe muster up our men with speed,
And let them march away to France amaine:
For we must aide the King against the Guise.
Be gone I say, tis time that we were there.

sp.speaker: Pleshe
sp.l: I goe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: That wicked Guise I feare me much will be,
The wine of that famous Realme of France:
For his aspiring thoughts aime at the crowne,
And He 'A takes his vantage on Religion,
To plant the Pope and popelings in the Realme,
And binde it wholy to the Sea of Rome:
But if that God doe prosper mine attempts,
And send us safely to arrive in France:
Wee'l beat him back, and drive him to his death,
That basely seekes the wine of his Realme.

div1.head: [Scene xix]
div1.stage: Enter the Captaine of the guarde, and three murtherers.

sp.speaker: Captaine
sp.l: Come on sirs, what, are you resolutely bent,
Hating the life and honour of the Guise?
What, will you not feare when you see him come?

sp.p:
Feare him said you? tush, were he heere, we would kill hin
presently.
O that his heart were leaping in my hand.
But when will he come that we may murther him?

sp.speaker: Captaine
sp.p:
Well , then ,
I see you are resolute.
Let us alone, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Captaine
sp.l: Then sirs take your standings within this Chamber , .
For anon the Guise will come.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: You will give us our money ? .

sp.speaker: Captaine
sp.l:
I, I, feare not : , stand close, so
,
be resolute:
sp.stage: [The murtherers go aside as if in the next room.]
sp.l: Now fals the star whose influence governes France,
Whose light was deadly to the Protestants:
Now must he fall and perish in his height.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now Captain of my guarde, are these murtherers ready?

sp.speaker: Captaine
sp.l: They be my good Lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But are they resolute and armde to kill,
Hating the life and honour of the Guise?

sp.speaker: Captaine
sp.l: I warrant ye you my Lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Then come proud Guise and heere disgordge thy brest,
Surchargde with surfet of ambitious thoughts:
Breath out that life wherein my death was hid,
And end thy endles treasons with thy death.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l:
Holla Halla
verlete varlet , hey: Epernoune, where is the King?

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: Mounted his royall Cabonet.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: I prethee tell him that the Guise is heere.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: And please your grace the Duke of Guise doth crave
Accesse unto your highnes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let him come in.
Come Guise and see thy traiterous guile outreacht,
And perish in the pit thou mad'st for me.

div1.stage: The Guise comes to the King.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Good morrow to your Majestie.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Good morrow to my loving Cousin of Guise.
How fares it this morning with your excellence?

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: I heard your Majestie was scarcely pleasde,
That in the Court I bare bear so great a traine.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: They were to blame that said I was displeasde,
And you good Cosin to imagine it.
Twere hard with me if I should doubt my kinne,
Or be suspicious of my deerest freends:
Cousin, assure you I am resolute,
Whatsoever Whatever any whisper in mine eares,
Not to suspect disloyaltye in thee,
And so sweet Cuz farwell.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: So,
Now sues the King for favour to the Guise,
And all his Minions stoup when I commaund:
Why this tis to have an army in the fielde . ,
Now by the holy sacrament I sweare,
As ancient Romanes over their Captive Lords,
So will I triumph over this wanton King,
And he shall follow my proud Chariots wheeles.
Now doe I but begin to look about,
And all my former time was spent in vaine:
Holde Sworde,

For in thee is the Duke of
Guises hope.
Villaine, why cost thou look so gastly? speake.
O pardon me my Lord of Guise.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Pardon thee, why what hast thou done?
O my Lord, I am one of them that is set to murder you.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: To murder me, villaine? .

sp.p:
I my Lord, the rest have taine their standings in the next
roome, therefore good my Lord goe not foorth.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Yet Caesar shall goe forth.
Let mean consaits, and baser men feare death,
Tut But they are pesants, I am Duke of Guise:
And princes with their lookes , ingender feare.
Stand close, he is comming, I know him by his voice.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: As pale as ashes, nay then tis time to look about.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Downe with him, downe with him.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Oh I have my deaths death wound, give me leave to speak.
Then pray to God, and aske forgivenes of the King.

sp.speaker: Guise
sp.l: Trouble me not, I neare offended him , .
Nor will I aske forgivenes of the King.
Oh that I have not power to stay my life,
Nor immortalitie to be reveng'd:
To dye by Pesantes, what a greefe is this?
Ah Sextus, be reveng'd upon the King,
Philip and Parma, I am slaine for you:
Pope excommunicate, Philip depose,
The wicked branch of curst Valois his Valois's line.
Vive la messe messa , perish Hugonets,
Thus Caesar did goe foorth, and thus he dyed dies .

sp.speaker: Captaine
sp.l:
What ,
have you done?
Then stay a while and Ile goe call the King,
But see where he comes.
My Lord, see where the Guise is slaine.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ah Oh this sweet sight is phisick to my soule,
Goe fetch his sonne for to beholde his death:
Surchargde with guilt of thousand massacres , :
Mounser of Loraine sinke away to hell,
And in In just remembrance of those bloudy broyles , :
To which thou didst alure me being alive:
And heere in presence of you all I sweare,
I nere was King of France untill this houre:
This is the traitor that hath spent my golde,
In making forraine warres and civile cruel broiles.
Did he not draw a sorte of English priestes
From Doway to the Seminary at Remes,
To hatch forth treason gainst their naturall Queene?

Did he not cause the King of
Spaines
huge fleete,
To threaten England and to menace me?
Did he not injure Mounser thats deceast?
Hath he not made me in the Popes defence,
To spend the treasure that should strength my land , :
In civill broiles between Navarre and me?
Tush, to be short, he meant to make me Munke,
Or else to murder me, and so be King.
Let Christian princes that shall heare of this,
(As all the world shall know our Guise is dead)
Rest satisfed with this that heer I sweare,
Nere was there King of France so yoakt as I.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: My Lord heer is his sonne.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Boy, look where your father lyes.

sp.speaker: Yong Guise
sp.l: My father slaine, who hath done this deed?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sirra twas I that slew him, and will slay
Thee thee too, and thou prove such a traitor.

sp.speaker: Yong Guise
sp.l: Art thou King, and hast done this bloudy deed?
Ile be revengde.

div1.stage: He offereth to throwe his dagger.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Away A way to prison with him, Ile clippe his winges
Or ere he passe my handes, away with him. Exit Boy.
But what availeth that this traitors dead,
When Duke Dumaine his brother is alive,
And that young Cardinall that is growne so proud?
Goe to the Governour of Orleance,
And will him in my name to kill the Duke.
Get you away and strangle the Cardinall. [Exit murtherers.]
These two will make one entire Duke of Guise,
Especially with our olde mothers helpe.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: My Lord, see where she comes, as if she droupt
To heare these newest

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And let her croup, my heart is light enough.
Mother, how like you this device of mine?
I slew the Guise, because I would be King.
King, why so thou wert before.
Pray God thou be a King now this is done.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nay he was King and countermanded me,
But now I will be King and rule my selfe,
And make the Guisians stoup that are alive.
I cannot speak for greefe : , when thou west bome,
I would that I had murdered thee my sonne.
My sonne: thou art a changeling, not my sonne.
I curse thee and exclaime thee miscreant,
Traitor to God, and to the realme of France.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Cry out, exclaime, houle till thy throat be hoarce,
The Guise is slaine, and I rejoyce therefore:
And now will I to armes, come Epernoune:
And let her greeve her heart out if she will.
Away, leave me alone to meditate . ,
Sweet Guise, would he had died so thou wert heere:
To whom shall I bewray my secrets now,
Or who will helpe to builde Religion?
The Protestants will glory and insulte,
Wicked Navarre will get the crowne of France,
The Popedome cannot stand, all goes to wrack,
And all for thee my Guise : , what may I doe?
But sorrow seaze upon my toyling soule,
For since the Guise is dead, I will not live.
sp.stage: Exit [the attendants taking up body of the Guise].

div1.head: [Scene xx]
div1.stage: Enter two [Murtherers] dragging in the Cardenall [of Loraine].

sp.speaker: Cardinall
sp.l: Murder me not, I am a Cardenall.
Wert thou the Pope thou mightst not scape from us.

sp.speaker: Cardinall
sp.l:
What ,
will you fyle your handes with Churchmens bloud ? ,

sp.p:
Shed your bloud,
O Lord no: for we entend to strangle you.

sp.speaker: Cardinall
sp.l: Then there is no remedye but I must dye ? .
No remedye, therefore prepare your selfe.

sp.speaker: Cardinall
sp.l: Yet lives
My brother Duke Dumaine, and many moe:
To revenge our deaths upon that cursed King , .
Upon whose heart may all the furies gripe,
And with their pawes drench his black soule in hell.
Yours my Lord Cardinall, you should have saide.
So, pluck amaine,
He is hard hearted, therfore pull with violence.
Come take him away.

div1.head: [Scene xxi]
div1.stage: Enter Duke Dumayn reading of a letter, with others.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: My noble brother murthered by the King,

Oh what may I doe, for
to revenge thy death?
The Kings alone, it cannot satisfie.
Sweet Duke of Guise our prop to leane upon,
Now thou art dead, heere is no stay for us:
I am thy brother, and ile revenge thy death,
And roote Valoys his Valois's line from forth of France,
And beate proud Burbon to his native home , .
That basely seekes to joyne with such a King , .
Whose murderous thoughts will be his overthrow.
Hee wild the Governour of Orleance in his name,
That I with speed should have beene put to death.
But thats prevented, for to end his life , .
And His life and all those traitors to the Church of Rome,
That durst attempt to murder noble Guise.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.p:
My Lord, I come to bring you newes, that your brother
the Cardinall of Loraine by the Kings consent is lately strangled
unto death.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: My brother Cardenall the Cardinal slaine and I alive?
O wordes of power to kill a thousand men.
Come let us away straight away and leavy men,
Tis warre that must asswage this the tyrantes pride.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.p:
My Lord, heare me but speak . ,
I am a Frier of the order of the Jacobyns, that for my conscience
sake will kill the King.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: But what doth move thee above the rest to doe the deed?

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.p:
O my Lord, I have beene a great sinner in my dayes, and
the deed is meritorious.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: But how wilt thou get opportunitye?

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: Tush my Lord, let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: Dumaine
sp.l: Frier come with me,
We will goe talke more of this within.

div1.head: [Scene xxii]
div1.stage: Sound Drumme and Trumpets, and enter the King of France, and Navarre, Epernoune, Bartus, Pleshe and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Brother of Navarre, I sorrow much,
That ever I was prov'd your enemy,
And that the sweet and princely minde you beare,
Was ever troubled with injurious warres:
I vow as I am lawfull King of France,
To recompence your reconciled love,
With all the honors and affections,
That ever I vouchsafte my dearest freends.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: It is enough if that Navarre may be ,
Esteemed faithfull to the King of France:
Whose service he may still commaund till to death.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thankes to my Kingly Brother of Navarre.
Then heere there wee'l lye before Lutetia Lucrecia Lutetia's walles,
Girting this strumpet Cittie with our siege,
Till surfeiting with our afflicting armes,
She cast her hatefull stomack to the earth.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
And it please your Majestie heere is a Frier of the
order of the Jacobins, sent from the President of Paris, that
craves accesse unto your grace.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let him come in.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: I like not this Friers look.
Twere not amisse my Lord, if he were searcht.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sweete Epernoune, our Friers are holy men,
And will not offer violence to their King,
For all the wealth and treasure of the world.
Frier, thou dost acknowledge me thy King ? :

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: I my good Lord, and will dye therein.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Then come thou neer, and tell what newes thou bringst.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: My Lord,
The President of Paris greetes your grace,
And sends send his dutie by these speedye lines,
Humblye craving your gracious reply.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ile read them Frier, and then Ile answere thee.

sp.speaker: Frier
sp.l: Sancte Jacobe Jacobus , now have mercye upon on me.

div1.stage: He stabs the King with a knife as he readeth the letter, and then the King getteth the knife and killes him.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: O my Lord, let him live a while.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No, let the villaine dye, and feele in hell,
Just torments for his trechery.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: What, is your highnes hurt?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Yes Navarre, but not to death I hope.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: God shield your grace from such a sodaine death:
Goe call a surgeon hether strait.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What irreligeous Pagans partes be these,
Of such as horde them of the holy church?
Take hence that damned villaine from my sight.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: Ah, had your highnes let him live,
We might have punisht him to for his deserts.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sweet Epernoune all Rebels under heaven,
Shall take example by his their punishment,
How they beare armes against their soveraigne.
Goe call the English Agent hether strait,
Ile send my sister England newes of this,
And give her warning of her trecherous foes.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l:
Pleaseth your grace to let the Surgeon search your
wound.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The wound I warrant ye you is deepe my Lord,
Search Surgeon and resolve me what thou seest.
Agent for England, send thy mistres word,
What this detested Jacobin hath done.
Tell her for all this that I hope to live,
Which if I doe, the Papall Monarck goes

To wrack , .
and an
his
th' antechristian kingdome falles.
These bloudy hands shall teare his triple Crowne,
And fire accursed Rome about his eares.
Ile fire his erased buildings and inforse incense enforce
The papall towers to kisse the lowly holy earth.
Navarre, give me thy hand, I heere do sweare,
To ruinate that this wicked Church of Rome,
That hatcheth up such bloudy practices.
And heere protest eternall love to thee,
And to the Queene of England specially especially ,
Whom God hath blest for hating Papestry Popery .

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: These words revive my thoughts and comforts comfort me,
To see your highnes in this vertuous minde.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Tell me Surgeon, shall I live?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Alas my Lord, the wound is dangerous,
For you are stricken with a poysoned knife.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l:
A poysoned knife ? , what ,
shall the French king dye,
Wounded and poysoned, both at once?

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: O that that damned villaine were alive againe,
That we might torture him with some new found death.

sp.speaker: Bartus
sp.l: He died a death too good, the devill of hell
Torture his wicked soule.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ah Oh curse him not sith since he is dead.
O the fatall poyson workes within my brest,
Tell me Surgeon and flatter not, may I live?

sp.speaker: Surgeon
sp.l: Alas my Lord, your highnes cannot live.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Surgeon, why saist thou so? the King may live.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Oh no Navarre, thou must be King of France.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Long may you live, and still be King of France.

sp.speaker: Epernoune
sp.l: Or else dye Epernoune.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sweet Epernoune thy King must dye. My Lords,
Fight in the quarrell of this valiant Prince,
For he is your lawfull King and my next heire:
Valoyses lyne ends in my tragedie.
Now let the house of Bourbon weare the crowne,
And may it never end in bloud as mine hath done.
Weep not sweet Navarre, but revenge my death.
Ah Epernoune, is this thy love to me?
Henry thy King wipes of these childish teares,
And bids thee whet thy sword on Sextus bones,
That it may keenly slice the Catholicks.
He loves me not the best the most that sheds most teares,
But he that makes most lavish of his bloud.
Fire Paris where these trecherous rebels lurke . ,
I dye Navarre, come beare me to my Sepulchre.
Salute the Queene of England in my name,
And tell her Henry dyes her faithfull freend.

sp.speaker: Navarre
sp.l: Come Lords, take up the body of the King , .
That we may see it honourably interde:
And then I vow for so to revenge his death,
As That Rome and all those popish Prelates there,
Shall curse the time that ere Navarre was King,
And rulde in France by Henries fatall death.

div1.stage: They march out with the body of the King, lying on foure mens shoulders with a dead march, drawingg weapons on the ground.
